text: I'm very happy to announce today the AWS
device form which is a managed
environment that allows you to build and
test your applications about a whole set
of real smartphones and tablets in the
AWS
Cloud the device Farm tests on real
smartphones and tablets we have racks
full of
them and it automatically tests them you
get very detailed reports back
um you can change configuration language
things like that and it integrates
through an API with your standard
workflow so you can build this whole
testing environment this device testing
environment and integrate it into how
you are already building your
applications and to actually walk you
through how this device F works I would
like to switch accents right now and
invite uh the one and only Dr Matt Wood
on
stage
thank good morning thank you very much
Vera so the AWS device Farm is an
attempt to dramatically simplify mobile
testing for Android and Firs devices it
allows developers to take their mobile
applications and run them against Real
devices which are housed on the AWS
Cloud you can run these applications
across a wide variety of physical
devices and across a wide variety of
Android and firos operating systems and
right there inside the service you can
configure the applications and the
devices themselves to meet various
different testing requirements run those
tests and then view detailed reports and
searchable logs so what I'd like to do
is give you a quick run through of what
this actually looks like in real life so
the run the test run is the foundational
unit of work for the AWS device farm and
it really has four components it has
your app it has a collection of tests it
has the devices that you want to run
those tests against and it has the state
of the devices that you want to put your
tests against and it's it's simple to
use as just four steps so the first
thing you do is you take your build your
binary this is exactly the same build
exactly the same binary that you would
use uh to test on a local device there's
no additional libraries or functionality
that you need to add to use device farm
and what we do is we take a look at that
binary and we pause out some metadata
including the minimum SDK that's
available and we use that to try and
recommend a collection of devices to
test that against once we've got your
app up there you can configure your
tests this is really straightforward if
you have a test Suite you can bring it
up using all these different Frameworks
uh if you don't have a test Suite you
can use the inbuilt fuzz testing uh this
throws random inputs into your
application which is always interesting
or you can upload your own Calabash
tests like we're doing here and we'll
take those we'll pause out the tests and
make them available the next step is to
configure and select the devices that
you want to run your tests against so
you can see what we've done here is
we've pre-select selected a collection
from a very very large pool of devices
which will meet your requirements and
what you can do is you can filter and
select a subset of a pool of those
devices to run your test against as well
so we'll just use our default selection
here we you can see we have a collection
of about seven different devices and
we'll go ahead and run the test but
before we do that we have to set and
configure the device state that we want
to run the Tes in and this is as easy as
adding additional data sets that you may
want to be present on the device you may
want to add other apps that you're going
to interact with on the device uh you
may want to turn on and off various
different network environments like
Wi-Fi or NPC you can also mock out the
location of your app of the device uh so
your app can read different locations
and you can test geofencing those sorts
of things and you can set the local of
your application so you can test
internationalization and once you've got
these three things configured four
things configured sorry you can just hit
run and that run will go off and be
provisioned on real devices in the AWS
Cloud running on device phone and what
you get back after a couple of minutes
is a detailed report that you can flick
through so you can see we're doing
pretty well here we have a big green uh
Bar Green is good in testing uh so we
have 28 tests passing uh we have two
that are failing and what the device
Farm is going to do is going to look at
all those failures and it's going to
group them together for us and so what
it's done here is it's identified that
that's actually although there's two
failures on two different devices it's
actually just a single unique failure so
now you can use this to pinpoint the
exact location in your code which is
causing that test to fail and you can go
fix it directly
it's a laser focus on identifying
problems with your application we can
then dive in to those individual logs
they being generated as a result of the
test run uh you can filter and search
these logs in various different ways and
we collect both the test output uh the
device output and also the harness
output so you can very quickly slice and
dice the output from your test to get a
feel for what's going on inside those
tests jumping back to the homepage you
can see a overview of the report you can
see which devices are passing the test
which devices are failing and the level
of failure and then what you can do is
you can dive into the results of the
particular test that was run in the
particular conditions on that particular
device so you can access all the
individual files and all the individual
output either come out of your test
suite and you can get right down into
the nitty-gritty all the way down to the
individual XML and Json files that are
produced as a result of your tests
whilst your test is running we record
the performance of the test so you can
look at CPU utilization of the device
memory utilization the amount of threads
which are being used this is very
helpful if you want to optimize for
Energy Efficiency we pull all of those
out as graphs which you can just see
right here in the console and finally
you can also programmatically take
screenshots as you're running your test
and we collect those screenshots off the
physical device and allow you to view
them directly here so the AWS device
Farm is an attempt to dramatically
simplify the way that mobile
applications are tested across a broad
set of Android and fire OS devices and
with that I'd like to thank you very
much and hand it over to Vera thank you
